tnodes.t:
@language html
Leo Vue

Leo Vue is a web app that can display files created with Leo, the open source outlining editor and IDE.

Leo has features that make it particularly suitable for documenting code and other complex documents.

Using Leo, you can create an outlined website or document like the one you are viewing. Content nodes can contain text, html, markdown or code. Content nodes can also point to other documents or websites.

Leo Vue was created using Vue.js, so you can add Vue.js components to your outline's content.

Content items in Leo outlines can be Markdown.
To mark content as Markdown, put the following in the first line of the node content:
@language md
When Leo Viewer encounters a node with @language md as the first line, it displays the (html) output, not the md source.

@language md
# A topic
This is fascinating.
## Another Topic
This one is less so.
### Fine Print
We would rather you not read this section.

@language md Content items in Leo outlines can be code. To mark content as code, put the following in the first line of the node content: @language languagename for example: @language javascript When Leo Viewer encounters a node with a language directive as the first line, it displays formatted code, unless the language is 'html' or 'md' in which case Leo Viewer displays the output view, not the source.

@language coffeescript
Client = require 'ftp' async = require 'async' remote_path ='/public_html/targetfolder/' local_path = 'data/' fs = require 'fs'
c = new Client() c.on 'ready', ()-> c.list remote_path, (err, list)-> if (err) then console.error 'list', err file_funcs = (getFileFunc file.name for file in list) async.series file_funcs, ()-> c.end()
getFileFunc = (name) -> (callback)-> if /csv$/.test name c.get remote_path + name, (err, stream)-> console.log 'Getting ', name if err then console.log 'get', err stream.once 'close', callback stream.pipe fs.createWriteStream local_path + name else console.log "Skipping", name callback()
c.connect( host : 'ftp.targethost.com' user : 'username@domain.com' password : 'password' )

@language md Content items in Leo outlines can be HTML. To mark content as HTML, put the following in the first line of the node content: @language html When Leo Viewer encounters a node with @language html as the first line, it displays the html output, not the html source.

@language html

Bee And Flower

An example of HTML content.

@language text
Content items in Leo outlines can be plain text.

This is just some regular text.
And now for some hipster ipsum:
Prism selvage farm-to-table, chillwave hexagon echo park tacos wayfarers shabby chic. Man braid chartreuse offal meggings. Messenger bag fap shabby chic blue bottle, typewriter la croix man braid chicharrones fashion axe mlkshk mustache narwhal. Single-origin coffee banh mi put a bird on it, lomo cred mumblecore schlitz flexitarian freegan retro. Edison bulb keytar single-origin coffee, direct trade plaid pug everyday carry ethical enamel pin. Viral neutra direct trade ramps semiotics intelligentsia, organic celiac food truck vice. Echo park PBR&B iPhone trust fund dreamcatcher.

Leo Nodes can be "cloned nodes". This means that two different nodes can point to the same shared content.
The nodes in this branch are clones of nodes appearing elsewhere in this document.
Leo Nodes can be @file nodes. This means that Leo keeps a link to an external file and will sync with any changes in the external file.

@language text
This section contains a brief introduction to some of the features of Leo.
This section contains a guide to using the Leo Vue program to view files created in Leo.

@language md
# Additional Features of Leo
Leo has more features than can be listed in a brief summary.
Some additional features include:
* IDE editing features in content pane * Fully programmable, the Leo Outline is available to Python scripts running in Leo. * Compose programs from Outlines * Create unit tests automatically with @test and @suite scripts * Import other outline formats

@language md
# Installing Leo
To install on Windows, unzip the following file and run leoApp.exe from the unzipped folder.
[Leo 5.3](https://sourceforge.net/projects/leo/files/Leo/Quick%20Install/Leo_5.3-b1_Win.zip/download)
For other environments, see the:
[Installation page on the Leo Site](http://leoeditor.com/installing.html)
For Mac and Linux users: you may need to install the Droid Sans Mono font (the default Leo font).

@language html << template >>
<< script >>
<< style >>
@language xml

@language css <!-- Add "scoped" attribute to limit CSS to this component only --> <style lang="sass"> .treeviewer margin-left: 0 height: 100% #left-pane ul list-style-type: none; padding: 0; padding-left: 10px; line-height: 1.4em list-style-type: none margin-bottom: 8px li white-space: nowrap min-width: 760px margin-bottom: 4px margin-top: 4px li > div padding-left: 4px </style>

@language md
# About Leo
Leo is a unique text editor and IDE that facilitates a new way of looking at text documents, including code files.
The purpose of this document is to make a brief introduction to creating tree-based content with Leo and displaying it with Leo Viewer.
Leo has features that make it particularly suitable for creating documentation of code.
More advanced users of Leo are able to use Leo to practice a type of "Literate Programming", that is, a style of programming where documentation comes first, and code is generated from the documentation or is developed in tandem with it.

@language md
# Installing and Using Leo Vue
To use Leo Vue, copy the files in the [dist folder at github](https://github.com/kaleguy/leovue) to your server. A web server is required, you can't simply open Leo Vue index.html file from your local file system. If you want to view files on your local machine without a server, use a node utility like 'http-server'.
<< Running Leo Vue from Github >>
The leo file that Leo Vue displays is located at 'static/docs.leo'. You can edit this leo file using the Leo program or replace it with your own file. You can change the name of the leo file that is loaded by editing the configuration parameters in index.html.
For a quick look at a Leo file, you can also drag and drop the file on to Leo Vue.

@language md # Leo Vue **Leo Vue** is a web app that can display files created with Leo, the open source outlining editor and IDE. Using **Leo**, you can create outlined content. Using **Leo Vue** you can display this content as a web page. The content you are reading was created in Leo. If you're reading this on the Leo Vue site, then this content is being displayed via the Leo Vue. Leo Vue is licensed under the MIT license.

@language md
You can create nodes that point to external sites.
To do this, create a node with a Markdown link in the title, for example:
``` [This is a link](http://www.example.com) ```
Leo Vue will show the external site in the content pane.
The next node has the following title:
``` [A URL Node](https://kaleguy.github.io/simpleng2admin/#/home) ```
Note that if Leo Vue is served via https (e.g. Github Pages) only https links will work here.
The second node in this section has the following title:
``` [Feature Introduction](https://kaleguy.github.io/leo-tutorials/feature-introduction.md) ```
This is a clone of one of the earlier nodes in this outline. In this case Leo Vue fetches the document and converts it to HTML before displaying it.

@language md
# Basic Configuration Options
Leo Vue loads static content from the 'static' folder. By default it will load a file named 'docs.leo'.
Currently Available Parameters: * **fileName**: name of leo file to load (without .leo extension) * **docTitle**: Title for the Leo file (will show in top menubar) * **showAppTitle**: Display 'Leo Vue' in upper left of app * **viewTypes**: Array of viewTypes (e.g. Outline, Line, Graphic Tree) to be displayed in upper right menu. * **baseMode**: Default viewType
Parameters can be passed in to the url or entered in index.html. See index.html for examples.
Using parameters on the URL:
``` http://www.mysite.com/leovue?title=MyFile&showapptitle=false
```

@language md
Leo Vue can load .leo files into nodes in a parent .leo file.
The child node of this node has the following title:
``` [Top](example.leo) ``` Since the title points to a .leo file, the leo file is loaded into the node when the node is clicked.
The subtree isn't loaded until you click on the node, so outlines can contain many child outlines and still have fast page load.
Note that search will not work on nodes that have not been loaded yet.
The nodes below this one are loaded from another .leo file.

@language html

An example Vue.js Youtube component added to an HTML content node.

@language md
Leo Vue is written in Vue.js, and Vue components can be added to content panes.
By default the following components are added to LeoVue.
* YouTube Viewer * Leaflet Maps * InfoCard * Tabs * Tables * Charts * SVG * Mermaid (diagrams) * MathJax
In your html content, add the Vue.js Youtube component like so: ``` <youtube video-id="pRnQFGskg9w" :player-width="320" :player-height="195"></youtube>
``` To see how to add other components, view the docs.leo file using Leo, and check out the contents of the following subnodes.

@language md
You can also run Leo Vue from github pages. Fork the repository on Github, then go to Settings - Github pages and choose 'master branch - docs folder'. The file 'docs.leo' in the docs/static folder will be viewable at username.github.io/myforkname/.

@language md
Besides the Vue components included with Leo Vue, you can easily add any other Vue.js component by installing it in Leo VUe and then declaring it in the main.js file.
For example:
``` import VueYouTubeEmbed from 'vue-youtube-embed'
Vue.use(VueYouTubeEmbed)
```
See the main.js file in the Leo Vue source for how other components are included with Leo Vue.

<info-card frontTitle=" Info Card " frontData=" The Vue Info Card component makes it easy to create simple flashcards. " backTitle=" Back Title " backData=" This is the back of the card. "/>
<info-card frontType="graph" frontTitle=" Graph Card " :frontData="[3, 2, 5, 9, 5, 10, 3, 5, 0, 0, 1, 8, 2, 9, 0]" backTitle=" Create a Graph Card " backData=" You can easily create graph cards like this one using the Vue Info Card component. Open the docs.leo file in the Leo Editor to see the source for this card. "/>

@language html

Use the Vue-Tabs component to add tabs to a content item.

Open the docs.leo file in Leo to see the source for this tab.

A content item using the tabs directive should use the html directive.

Second tab content

Third tab content

@language html

Random Title

Add tooltips to text with the Vue Tooltip Component.

@language md
The Vue-Chartjs component is included by default with Leo Vue.
The Vue-Chartjs component isn't used directly, it is necessary to subclass each graph type.
The following Chartjs components are included by default with Leo Vue:
* Line Chart * Bar Chart * Pie Chart * Doughnut Chart * Polar Chart
The chart components can refer to data in nodes in the Leo document.
In this section, a number of example charts and data sets are displayed.
Some of the examples are adapted from the excellent [Chartjs Intro articles by Tobias Ahlin](http://tobiasahlin.com/blog/introduction-to-chartjs/).

Multiple formulas with text.
<mj> \sum_{n=1}^k \frac{1}{n} ≻ \int_1^{k+1} \frac{1}{x} dx = \ln(k+1) </mj>
Another formula:
<mj> \sum_{n = 0}^\infty \frac{(-1)^{n}}{2n+1} = 1 - \frac{1}{3} + \frac{1}{5} - \frac{1}{7} + \cdots = \frac{\pi}{4} </mj>

@language md
Nodes in Leo Vue can contain data, and this data can be used by Vue components.
There are two types of data nodes:
* **dataSets**: these contain JSON data. * **dataTables**: these contain CSV data.

@language md
DataTables can be used to put csv data into a Leo node, for viewing with Leo Vue.
The first word after the @dataTable directive is the name of the dataTable, and the rest of the node title becomes the dataTable title.
This data is from the [Wikipedia article on World Population](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_population#Population_growth_by_region).

@language html
<line-chart dataTable="worldpop" :gridLines="true" />
<bar-chart dataTable="worldpop" col="2050" title="Predicted Population (millions) in 2050" />
<pie-chart dataTable="worldpop" col="2050" title="Predicted Population (millions) in 2050" />
<doughnut-chart dataTable="worldpop" col="2050" title="Predicted Population (millions) in 2050" />
<polar-chart dataTable="worldpop" col="2050" title="Predicted Population (millions) in 2050" />

@language md A dataSet is a Leo node with a @dataSet directive. It contains JSON data. The data in a dataSet can be referred to by name in chart or table components. For example, the first chart in this node contains the following component markup: 
      <line-chart :dataSet="'set1'" :gridLines="true" />

@language md
A dataTable is a Leo node with a @dataTable directive. It contains csv data.
The data in a dataTable can be referred to by name in chart or table components.
This data in these charts is from the [Wikipedia article on World Population](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_population#Population_growth_by_region).

@language html

A basic table component is included for displaying table data. The table component displays data from a dataTable node (see the [[Data]] node).

@language md
Leo Vue is currently at version 1.8.4
Leo Vue 1.8.x is currently is only tested in Chrome and may not display correctly in other browsers.
Current features include: * Display Leo content including markdown, html and code highlighting * Bookmarkable nodes * Node titles can be urls to markdown files * Node titles can be urls to html pages * Outline and Inline views * Drag and drop a Leo file to display * Graphic trees * Load Leo files into subtrees * Nested menu mode * Clickable section links inside content * Content nodes can have [[ Vue.js Components ]] * Search * SEO version (static html files) * Nested presentations with Reveal.js * Summary nodes: Kanban and Flowchart * Outline nodes: outline a target page * RSS nodes: point a node to an RSS feed to have content area display HTML version. * Nodes with templated data, e.g. @xml and @json nodes.
Planned features not yet supported: * Keyboard support * Form.io support

@language html

The table component below is powered by spatie/vue-table-component.

If you view this node in Leo, you'll see that in this example all of the data and options are passed directly to the component.

@language html

This example uses the vc-table component to display the data from the worldpop dataTable.

@language md
Leo Vue includes a component for displaying diagrams written for the [Mermaid library](https://mermaidjs.github.io/). Since this library is large it isn't included with Leo Vue, but the default index.html file has a link to the Mermaid CDN.
In order to use the Mermaid component, the CDN link must be in the Leo Vue index.html and the internet needs to be accessible. Or, you can add the Mermaid files directly to your own installation of Leo Vue.
Leo Vue can also display any content supported by modern browsers, including SVG.

@language html

A Sequence Diagram with Mermaid

See the Leo file for the source for this diagram. sequenceDiagram participant Alice participant Bob Alice->>John: Hello John, how are you? loop Healthcheck John->>John: Fight against hypochondria end Note right of John: Rational thoughts prevail... John-->>Alice: Great! John->>Bob: How about you? Bob-->>John: Jolly good!

@language html

A simple GANNT diagram with Mermaid.


      gantt
      dateFormat  YYYY-MM-DD
      title Adding GANTT diagram to mermaid
      section A section
      Completed task            :done,    des1, 2014-01-06,2014-01-08
      Active task               :active,  des2, 2014-01-09, 3d
      Future task               :         des3, after des2, 5d
      Future task2              :         des4, after des3, 5d
gantt dateFormat YYYY-MM-DD title Adding GANTT diagram to mermaid section A section Completed task :done, des1, 2014-01-06,2014-01-08 Active task :active, des2, 2014-01-09, 3d Future task : des3, after des2, 5d Future task2 : des4, after des3, 5d

@language html

Multiple Graphs in one Diagram

      graph TB
      c1-->a2
      subgraph one
      a1-->a2
      end
      subgraph two
      b1-->b2
      end
      subgraph three
      c1-->c2
      end
graph TB c1-->a2 subgraph one a1-->a2 end subgraph two b1-->b2 end subgraph three c1-->c2 end

@language html

Since Leo Vue is a web viewer, it supports any content supported by modern browsers, including SVG.

A simple SVG wrapper component is included to make SVG sizing for the Leo Vue content pane easier.

Below is an example of an SVG chart created on draw.io, exported to SVG and displayed with v-svg.

@language md
# Presentations with Leo Vue
Leo Vue uses the Reveal.js library to display presentations.
Create content in Leo, including content with Vue Components.
Display the content using the @presentation directive.
Presentations can be nested.

Presentations with Leo Vue

Create content with the Leo Outlining Editor.

Display it with Leo Vue.

Leo Vue uses the Reveal.js Library to display presentations.

  • Create intereactive slide desks using HTML
  • Create decks in Leo
  • Display with Leo Vue
  • Content can include Vue.js components

Leo

Created by Edward K. Ream

  • Outlining Editor
  • A single element can be on multiple nodes
  • Scriptable IDE
  • Metatext Editor

@language html

Vue.js

Created by Evan You / @youyuxi

  • App/Component Framework
  • Small and Fast, Easy to Learn
  • Many Components Available
  • 74k+ Stars on Github
  • No Corporate Agenda

Vue.js components in Presentations

  • Charts (Chartjs)
  • Tables from Data Nodes
  • Infocards
  • SVG and Mermaid Diagrams
  • YouTube Videos
  • Custom Layouts
Charts

Math

Math symbols via the MathJax Library

Tables

Tables with Sort / Format

@language md
#### Markdown
Leo Vue supports Markdown
* use the @language md directive * node text will be converted to html * this slide was created with Markdown
The Reveal.js Demo Presentation

Reveal.js

The HTML Presentation Framework

Created by Hakim El Hattab / @hakimel

Hello There

reveal.js enables you to create beautiful interactive slide decks using HTML. This presentation will show you examples of what it can do.

@language html

Vertical Slides

Slides can be nested inside of each other.

Use the Space key to navigate through all slides.


Basement Level 1

Nested slides are useful for adding additional detail underneath a high level horizontal slide.

Basement Level 2

That's it, time to go back up.

Point of View

Press ESC to enter the slide overview.

Hold down alt and click on any element to zoom in on it using zoom.js. Alt + click anywhere to zoom back out.

@language html

Fragments

Hit the next arrow...

... to step through ...

... a fragmented slide.

This slide has fragments which are also stepped through in the notes window.

Fragment Styles

There's different types of fragments, like:

grow

shrink

fade-out

fade-up (also down, left and right!)

current-visible

Highlight red blue green

Transition Styles

You can select from different transitions, like:
None - Fade - Slide - Convex - Concave - Zoom

Themes

reveal.js comes with a few themes built in:
Black (default) - White - League - Sky - Beige - Simple
Serif - Blood - Night - Moon - Solarized

@language html

Slide Backgrounds

Set data-background="#dddddd" on a slide to change the background color. All CSS color formats are supported.

Image Backgrounds

<section data-background="image.png">

Tiled Backgrounds

<section data-background="image.png" data-background-repeat="repeat" data-background-size="100px">

Video Backgrounds

<section data-background-video="video.mp4,video.webm">

... and GIFs!

img-left

  • custom component
  • use Vue templates
  • create page layouts
this is the footer

@props data-transition="slide" data-background="#4d7e65" data-background-transition="zoom"

Background Transitions

Different background transitions are available via the backgroundTransition option. This one's called "zoom". 

Reveal.configure({ backgroundTransition: 'zoom' })

@props data-transition="slide" data-background="#b5533c" data-background-transition="zoom"

Background Transitions

You can override background transitions per-slide. 

<section data-background-transition="zoom">

Speaker View

There's a speaker view. It includes a timer, preview of the upcoming slide as well as your speaker notes.

Press the S key to try it out.

Oh hey, these are some notes. They'll be hidden in your presentation, but you can see them if you open the speaker notes window (hit 's' on your keyboard).

Take a Moment

Press B or . on your keyboard to pause the presentation. This is helpful when you're on stage and want to take distracting slides off the screen.

Much more

  • Right-to-left support
  • Extensive JavaScript API
  • Auto-progression
  • Parallax backgrounds
  • Custom keyboard bindings

THE END

- Try the online editor
- Source code & documentation

@language md
#### Shared Slides
Because of Leo's cloned nodes, slides can be shared among multiple presentations.
The next slide is from the << Reveal.js >> presentation.
<info-card frontTitle=" Info Card " frontData=" The Vue Info Card component makes it easy to create simple flashcards. " backTitle=" Back Title " backData=" This is the back of the card. "/>

<info-card frontType="graph" frontTitle=" Infocard with Graph " :frontData="[3, 2, 5, 9, 5, 10, 3, 5, 0, 0, 1, 8, 2, 9, 0]" backTitle=" Create a Graph Card " backData=" Infocards can also have simple graphs."/>

@language md
# Kanban
Some people find Leo outlines to be a good way to organize to-do lists and projects.
However, if you have your projects in Leo, you still might want to be able to display a level of your project list as a Kanban board, so that others can easily see that section's progress.
Using the @kanban directive, you can create a kanban board from a node. The next level node become the columns of the boards, and the lower levels are displayed in the nested viewer.
The nested viewer component makes it possible to display just the selected parts of a tree, so a large subtree can be viewable in a single kanban column.
Need a script to download all CDNs for running locally.
height: 600 click: goto
This is the A node.
style: fill:#f9f,stroke:#333,stroke-width:4px text: yes

@language md
# Summary Nodes
Leo Vue can summarize the contents of a subtree. Currently there are two directives that do this:
**@kanban**: Create a Kanban board from the subtree.
**@mermaid** Create a Mermaid diagram from the subtree. To specifiy the digram type, use:
* @mermaidlr: left - right * @mermaidrl: right - left * @mermaidtd: top - down
You can write your own summary component by adapting the code of an existing summary component. The component code shows how to access data in the Leo Vue tree and use it in a new Vue component.

# Mermaid
Mermaid is a javascript library for creating diagrams. Leo Vue can create (and then display) Mermaid markup to summarize the contents of a subtree. Since Leo subtrees can contain cloned nodes, the resulting diagrams can be can be more complex than a simple outline.
Mermaid directives:
* **@mermaidtd:** create a top down diagram * **@mermaidlr:** create a left right diagram * **@mermaidrl:** create a right left diagram
Clicking on the icon in the upper right of the content pane displays the Mermaid markup, which you can use in other environments that support Mermaid.
Options (in YAML format) can be placed in the directive node, e.g:
``` height: 400 click: goto // click will go to node, otherwise displays popup rounded: // or 'circle' or 'square' fa: user // any font awesome icon name fill: "#85FD31,stroke:#333,stroke-width:4px;width:100px" ```
height: 350
height: 350
type: lr height: 600 circle: fill: "#f9f,stroke:#333,stroke-width:4px;width:100px" fa: user rounded: fill: "#ccf,stroke:#33f,stroke-width:1px" fa: star

### Brent is a problem
Brent is used in a lot of projects. He has made himself indispensable, slowing the entire system down.
Alice is famous in computer circles, but little is known about her.
height: 450 circle: fa: user
height: 400 rounded: fa: user fill: "#85FD31,stroke:#333,stroke-width:4px;width:100px"

# This is user D
The real name of user D is Pat.
sort-item etc.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evaporating_Cloud

@language html

A Leo Vue URL looks like this:

https://kaleguy.github.io/leovue/#/t/8/

The format is: # + display type + node number.

You can use a more readable format for bookmarking or distributing URLs:

https://kaleguy.github.io/leovue/#/t/More About Leo Vue

In other words, you can replace the node number with the node title.

You can also specify a parent node, using this syntax:

https://kaleguy.github.io/leovue/#/t/Sample Content~A Note About Something

Nodes using the @outline directive (which loads and outlines a target site) use a different format, the outline node name must be specified first, then an asterisk, then the node title.

https://kaleguy.github.io/leovue/#/t/Dinosaurs*Etymology
A URL node can be a simple website displayed in the content area.
& in RSS

@language md
Using the @xml directive, you can retrieve and format XML content. The content will be formatted with the xsl template that you specify.
For example:
``` @xml [New York Weather](http://w1.weather.gov/xml/current_obs/display.php?stid=KLGA) ```
You need to tell the directive what template to use to format the xml. So in the body of the following node in the leo file, put
``` template: weather ```
By default, Leo Vue comes with just an 'rss' and 'weather' template. These templates are in lib/xsl.js. You can add more templates to this file to format other xml sources.
template: weather

@language md
Using the @json directive, you can retrieve and format JSON data with lodash templates.
For example:
``` @json [NYC Weather](https://tranquil-headland-86417.herokuapp.com/weather/10021) ```
You need to tell the directive what template to use to format the JSON. So in the body of the following node in the leo file, specify the template. You can also add other data that will be added to the JSON retrieved from the data endpoint.
``` template: weather location: NYC Central Park source: OpenWeather Map ```
By default, Leo Vue comes with just a 'weather' template for JSON data from OpenWeather Map. This template is in lib/lodash-template.js. You can add more templates to this file to format other JSON data sources.
template: weather location: NYC Central Park source: OpenWeather Map

@language md
Using the @rg directive, you can load an abstract from ResearchGate into the content for a node.
In this case, the markdown syntax isn't used, just put "@rg" + the page title.
For example:
``` @rg 309182447_Validating_self-paced_sentence-by-sentence_reading_story_comprehension_recall_and_narrative_transportation ```
template: openbooks comments: This is a math book. It was on the Openlibrary site.

@language md
Using the @book directive, you can use a book title and ISBN to load book details into the content for a node.
If you want to add comments to the book listing, add for example "comments: My comments" to the node body. You can also add star ratings in the node body, e.g. "rating: 4".
For example:
``` @book [Evolution of Civilizations](0913966576) ```
The data for the book is taken from OpenLibrary.org. If data for the book you want to display is missing, you can add it to the OpenLibary database.
comments: This is a book about Mathematics.

rating: 5 comments: | This beautifully written book gives the reader the tools to analyze history from the most important patterns.
These patterns are illustrated by an overview of the last 3000 years of history.
